s.text: When Will writes about baseball, America pays attention.
And given that his columns are ephemera, why shouldn't Will give them up for his true love?
He is a long shot: He lacks business experience, and he alienated owners with his pro-player stance during the strike.
Why this has happened has less to do with Will than it does with the state of the newspaper column.
In Men at Work , Will found a smart new way for an average fan to think about the game.
He was just one smart voice among dozens.

He never aspired to be a Lippmann and rejects the idea of Government by Columnist: "I don't want to live in a country blown about by gusts of wind raised by journalists.
Will, who was supposed to be the Walter Lippmann of this conservative era, finds himself in a curious position.
